commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Add VIF_DELETED notification event to Nova""

This reverts commit 6575db592c92791a51540134192bc86465940283.

Depends-on: I998b6bb80cc0a81d665b61b8c4a424d7219c666f

DocImpact
If Neutron is upgraded to Liberty before the Nova API is,
the Nova API log will contain errors complaining that it doesn't
understand this new event. Nothing will be broken, but there will
be an error every time a port is deleted until Nova is upgraded.

Change-Id: I7aae44e62d2b1170bae31c3492148bfd516fb78b

commit_message:
Prevent bond and bridge names looks like name of

another type network interface.
i.e. old and new ethernet names, infiniband cards, wifi cards, etc...

Change-Id: I55383cdb59bead345f0127b826ec4d8a127b34a8
Related-bug: #1483307
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/68/211568/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not val =~ /^[a-z][0-9a-z\-]*[0-9a-z]$/ if val.length > 15 fail("Bridge name too long: '#{val}'. Allowed not more 15 chars.") end if ! [Regexp.new(/^bond.*/), Regexp.new(/^wlan.*/), Regexp.new(/^lo\d*/), Regexp.new(/^eth.*/), Regexp.new(/^en[ospx]\h+/), Regexp.new(/^em\d+/), Regexp.new(/^p\d+p\d+/), Regexp.new(/^ib\d*/), ].select{|x| x.match(val)}.empty? fail("Wrong bridge name: '#{val}'")

commit_message:
Disable failing vpn tests

Until one of the solutions proposed in [1] are complete, and until the
vpn plugin is added to this repo, failing tests should be commented so
as to not block ongoing development.

[1]: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/vpn-test-changes

Related-bug: #1484148
Change-Id: I9a41bd74a1a55c0b0137c7b4453eaf7517c43483

commit_message:
Fix printing of errors in IPA

Exception messages weren't being bubbled up to the API because the
base exception class wasn't printing correctly. This adds a string
and representation function to ensure they print properly and show
up correctly when debugging interactively.

Cleaned up the `message` attr on the exception classes. It looks
like they started out all without a period, but started adding them
later. Changed classes that were setting error `details` == `message`
to use the default details provided in RESTError.

Change-Id: I1ce256585c9a574e1d1f857c7dc4c417a56b913b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/92/211692/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(JoshNang) `message` should not end with a period def __str__(self): return "{}: {}".format(self.message, self.details) def __repr__(self): """Should look like RESTError('message: details')""" return "{}('{}')".format(self.__class__.__name__, self.__str__()) message = 'Error in call to ironic-api' message = 'Error heartbeating to agent API' message = 'Error getting configuration from Ironic' message = 'Error downloading image' message = 'Error verifying image checksum' message = 'Error writing image to device' message = 'Configdrive is too large for intended partition' message = 'Error writing configdrive to device' message = 'Error rebooting system' message = 'Configuring agent from virtual media failed' message = 'Agent is not associated with an Ironic node' message = 'No valid HardwareManager found' message = 'HardwareManager method is not compatible with hardware' message = 'Clean step failed' message = 'Error starting iSCSI target' 'the image onto')
deleted_lines: message = 'Error in call to ironic-api.' message = 'Error heartbeating to agent API.' message = 'Error getting configuration from Ironic.' message = 'Error downloading image.' message = 'Error verifying image checksum.' message = 'Error writing image to device.' message = 'Configdrive is too large for intended partition.' message = 'Error writing configdrive to device.' message = 'Error rebooting system.' message = 'Configuring agent from virtual media failed.' message = 'Agent is not associated with an Ironic node.' message = 'No valid HardwareManager found.' message = 'HardwareManager method is not compatible with hardware.' message = 'Clean step failed.' message = 'Error starting iSCSI target.' commit_message:
Compute: replace incorrect instance object with dict

Commit 171e5f8b127610d93a230a6f692d8fd5ea0d0301 updated security
groups instances to be instance objects. These are not instance objects
and are the instances stored in the database.

Change-Id: If79b5d4592e1ecbd860aa53e2d976b658c9227d0
Closes-bug: #1461065
(cherry picked from commit 99b56a47a3654590a7fdabfb34f073911393c471)

commit_message:
Increase internal_ip and management_ip column size

When using Ipv6 a column size of 15 is no big enough. We need to
increase these two columns to 45.

Closes-bug: 1470999
Change-Id: I5843878bb441748d80e2d7de02a232cf1d937d88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/67/203067/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _add_instance_ipv6(self, ctx, ng_id): instance = { "instance_name": "additional_vm_ipv6", "internal_ip": "FE80:0000:0000:0000:0202:B3FF:FE1E:8329", "management_ip": "FE80:0000:0000:0000:0202:B3FF:FE1E:8329" } return self.api.instance_add(ctx, ng_id, instance) def test_add_instance_ipv6(self): ctx = context.ctx() cluster_db_obj = self.api.cluster_create(ctx, SAMPLE_CLUSTER) _id = cluster_db_obj["id"] ng_id = cluster_db_obj["node_groups"][-1]["id"] count = cluster_db_obj["node_groups"][-1]["count"] self._add_instance_ipv6(ctx, ng_id) cluster_db_obj = self.api.cluster_get(ctx, _id) for ng in cluster_db_obj["node_groups"]: if ng["id"] != ng_id: continue ng.pop('tenant_id') self.assertEqual(count + 1, ng["count"]) self.assertEqual("additional_vm_ipv6", ng["instances"][0]["instance_name"]) def test_update_instance_ipv6(self): ctx = context.ctx() ip = "FE80:0000:0000:0000:0202:B3FF:FE1E:8329" cluster_db_obj = self.api.cluster_create(ctx, SAMPLE_CLUSTER) _id = cluster_db_obj["id"] ng_id = cluster_db_obj["node_groups"][-1]["id"] instance_id = self._add_instance(ctx, ng_id) self.api.instance_update(ctx, instance_id, {"management_ip": ip}) cluster_db_obj = self.api.cluster_get(ctx, _id) for ng in cluster_db_obj["node_groups"]: if ng["id"] != ng_id: continue self.assertEqual(ip, ng["instances"][0]["management_ip"])

subject: Use the oslo_utils.timeutils 'StopWatch' class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-10 23:25:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/f8fe81abc337dcf7ecd5965c04636d7878176383', 'message': "Use the oslo_utils.timeutils 'StopWatch' class

Instead of using time.time() to keep track of durations
the stop watch class provides this same functionality in a
nicely made helper class. It also internally uses monotonically
increasing time so that drifts/going backwards should not be
possible so it seems like a nice change to just use it vs computing
similar information.

Change-Id: Ic8906f42f6997412fffe950d4833dc2ad88ecf28

commit_message:
Use the oslo_utils.timeutils 'StopWatch' class

Instead of using time.time() to keep track of durations
the stop watch class provides this same functionality in a
nicely made helper class. It also internally uses monotonically
increasing time so that drifts/going backwards should not be
possible so it seems like a nice change to just use it vs computing
similar information.

Change-Id: Ic8906f42f6997412fffe950d4833dc2ad88ecf28

commit_message:
get_supported_boot_devices() returns static device list

Returning a static device list currently is only applicable
to x86 based architectures. If a node references for instance
sparc architecture, then "pxe" boot is not supported, however
"wanboot" is. The driver referenced by the node should be able
to return a custom boot device list dependent on the architecture
of the node. However to achieve this the task needs to be passed
as an argument in get_supported_boot_devices()

Change-Id: I5ae70ee84309dffb7d7bca4ac5cba28b01b7c414
Closes-Bug: #1391598
Implements: blueprint supported-boot-device-list

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for fixed_ip_associate_*

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
fixed_ip_associate_*

the follow functions call db fixed_ip_associate_* API
1. allocate_for_instance, contex has been elevated.
2. add_fixed_ip_to_instance, it does not need to require admin previlege.
   and bug 1432455 was filed for it.

the follow functions call db fixed_ip_associate_pool API.
1. NetworkManager._get_dhcp_ip, contex has been elevated.

Closes-Bug: 1432455
Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: Ia33080c1681b139dbca72bfd5c9810e8fbea6719

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for instance_get_all_hung_in_rebooting

'instance_get_all_hung_in_rebooting' isn't invoked by any code anymore.
It will be removed after object major version bump. This patch just remove
the useless hard-code permission checks decorator.

Partially implements bp nova-api-policy-final-part

Change-Id: Ife710727b9df8b040b831efff3c4d24d2ec3df78

commit_message:
Refactor unit test for InstanceGroup objects

The goal of this patch was to remove the use of the database in the unit
tests for the InstanceGroup objects. We now mock out all database
interactions in the object unit tests and verify that the calls to the
DB API are appropriate.

Change-Id: I98740029ed1115491438e93bfcb981b1f1bd7095
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/197228/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import copyimport mock from oslo_utils import timeutils from nova import objects _TS_NOW = timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True) # o.vo.fields.DateTimeField converts to tz-aware and # in process we lose microsecond resolution. _TS_NOW = _TS_NOW.replace(microsecond=0) _DB_UUID = str(uuid.uuid4()) _INST_GROUP_DB = { 'id': 1, 'uuid': _DB_UUID, 'user_id': 'fake_user', 'project_id': 'fake_project', 'name': 'fake_name', 'policies': ['policy1', 'policy2'], 'members': ['instance_id1', 'instance_id2'], 'deleted': False, 'created_at': _TS_NOW, 'updated_at': _TS_NOW, 'deleted_at': None, } class _TestInstanceGroupObject(object): @mock.patch('nova.db.instance_group_get', return_value=_INST_GROUP_DB) def test_get_by_uuid(self, mock_db_get): obj = objects.InstanceGroup.get_by_uuid(mock.sentinel.ctx, _DB_UUID) mock_db_get.assert_called_once_with(mock.sentinel.ctx, _DB_UUID) self.assertEqual(obj.members, _INST_GROUP_DB['members']) self.assertEqual(obj.policies, _INST_GROUP_DB['policies']) self.assertEqual(obj.uuid, _DB_UUID) self.project_id = _INST_GROUP_DB['project_id'] self.user_id = _INST_GROUP_DB['user_id'] self.name = _INST_GROUP_DB['name'] @mock.patch('nova.db.instance_group_get_by_instance', return_value=_INST_GROUP_DB) def test_get_by_instance_uuid(self, mock_db_get): obj = objects.InstanceGroup.get_by_instance_uuid( mock.sentinel.ctx, mock.sentinel.instance_uuid) mock_db_get.assert_called_once_with( mock.sentinel.ctx, mock.sentinel.instance_uuid) self.assertEqual(obj.members, _INST_GROUP_DB['members']) self.assertEqual(obj.policies, _INST_GROUP_DB['policies']) self.assertEqual(obj.uuid, _DB_UUID) self.project_id = _INST_GROUP_DB['project_id'] commit_message:
Port cleanup on failed VM instance launch

Currently if a VM instance launch fails, stale VM ports are left behind

Change-Id: Ia243ac0cca92ed52fb5c4c27412bb0a8390dbaac
Closes-Bug: 1423453

added_lines: if api.neutron.is_port_profiles_supported(): for nic in nics: try: api.neutron.port_delete(request, nic['port-id']) except: msg = (_('Port not deleted for port-id (%s).') % nic['port-id']) exceptions.handle(request, msg)

commit_message:
Incorrect variable name is declared

Incorrect variable name is declared in
test_validate_key_cert_key_cant_read() method.

In the second 'with' statement, changed variable name
from keyf to certf.

Closes-Bug: #1482144

commit_message:
cleanup NovaObjectDictCompat from numa object

cleanup subclassing on NovaObjectDictCompat and fix subsequent
tests and code associated with nova/objects/numa.py

Due to the exhaustive nature of changes, the cleanup is done
one object at a time.

This is the fifth patch of the series.
There shall be more patches to follow for other objects.

Related to blueprint liberty-objects

Change-Id: I7467a8640ea67f0a01751c2b3112ae56953978d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/210480/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Addresses Detail page inconsistencies & code style

This is a first pass at creating a similar appearance for every detail
page, as well as cleaning up the code base.

- Adds a common _detail page
- Removes unnecessary classes and nesting from HTML
- Minor CSS change for aesthetics
- Edits tests to reflect the new template used

Change-Id: I9e3e3869c4c7ca3a80164a247c6838f9bb591e41
Partial-Bug: 1413823

commit_message:
Remove POSIX users, groups, and file modes.

This patch removes File resources which should be delivered by packaging
tools.  These resources (files, directories, modes, users, and group
attributes) could be in conflict with different OS packaging systems
which isn't a desired result.

Change-Id: I50303f0931173f326e9bf7260a713b1ae700890c
Closes-Bug: #1458915

commit_message:
Implement listing actions supported

As congress supports executing actions, we need a way to query
available actions that a datasource driver can execute. This patch
implements a new API to support listing actions.

Change-Id: I1c976ddb556ce5dbf6ce954af4a2fe3cc9460caa
Implements-blueprint: add-action-listing

commit_message:
Fix the unit tests for python3

Searchlight contains lots of problems with compatibility for python 3.
The unit tests for python 3 should pass.

Closes-Bug: 1482225

commit_message:
WIP: Remove old system information panel

Remove old system information panel, remove the ng* prefixes,
from the new panel filenames, and enable the new panel.

Co-Authored-By: Kristine Brown <kbrown@thoughtworks.com>

Change-Id: I2d26a8bf965768afc66007898c3ed240047b5279
Partially-Implements: blueprint ng-system-information

commit_message:
libvirt: call host.get_capabilities after checking for bad numa versions

The arch check in _has_numa_support comes after checking for bad libvirt
numa versions, so move the host.get_capabilities call down to where it's
actually needed since we might return before that.

Change-Id: I2edbe613f84b5049ee88e9436be80430b886ac20

deleted_lines: with mock.patch.object(drvr._host, 'get_capabilities'): for i in xrange(2): self.assertFalse(drvr._has_numa_support())

added_lines: SERVICES = 'services' services_translator = { 'translation-type': 'HDICT', 'table-name': SERVICES, 'selector-type': 'DOT_SELECTOR', 'field-translators': ({'fieldname': 'id', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'binary', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'host', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'zone', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'status', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'state', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'updated_at', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'disabled_reason', 'translator': value_trans})} floating_ips_translator, services_translator] self._translate_services(self.nova_client.services.list()) def _translate_services(self, obj): row_data = NovaDriver.convert_objs(obj, NovaDriver.services_translator) self.state[self.SERVICES] = set() for table, row in row_data: assert table == self.SERVICES self.state[table].add(row)

commit_message:
Adds spec for creating a key manager with Barbican to Ironic

This will add a Barbican implementation of the generic key manager interface.

Change-Id: If63e5565ccbf7b74cf5f495971580a44f225dd1c
Depends-On: Icb5d0eb36491b5eff9137173206654b002e3bd55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/09/188609/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== Create key manager interface for Ironic using Barbican ====================================================== URL to Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/barbican-key-mgr Ironic doesn't have any coherent system for storing or retrieving secrets, or performing any other operation a key manager would perform. Creating a generic key management system used in Ironic would aid us with operations like storing and rotating passwords used for accessing Swift or certain driver functionality. Integrating with Barbican in particular helps us meet the goals of secure secret storage and retrieval as well as keeping us in line with a major OpenStack project. Problem description =================== Currently, secrets like passwords and authentication tokens are stored either statically in configuration files or a node's driver_info attribute. This both decentralizes the way secrets are stored across Ironic and makes it difficult to manage and rotate secrets. Use cases for deployers of Ironic include managing Keystone credentials, RabbitMQ passwords, IPMI, DRAC, and iLO passwords, and many other deployment-specific secrets. Proposed change =============== Create an interface that will call python-barbicanclient, an interface to Barbican for Python programs, to support generating, storing, and presenting keys to Ironic from Barbican. A base class will be implemented with a subclass that uses Barbican to manage keys and a subclass that does static password retrieval from a configuration file. The subclass allowing static configuration will exist to allow deployers to continue using their system without setting up a new Barbican deployment. Additionally, it will make transitioning to the use of the key manager easier since deployers can leave their configuration files mostly the same in their deployments if they wish to continue specifying secrets in configuration files. The key manager will look similar to Nova's in implementation, since Nova's key manager has both an implementation that pulls secrets from a configuration file and an implementation that uses Barbican. An example use of the key manager in one or more places that currently use secrets will be included in the patch creating the key manager to assist further patches in implementing use of the key manager across Ironic. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is to continue using static configuration files for secrets. This isn't a viable long-term option because an enterprise-grade Ironic deployment needs to have ways to rotate keys in and out of use quickly in case of compromise. Another alternative is to invoke python-barbicanclient directly, but this would lack the flexibility needed if certain deployments of Ironic wish to continue using secrets in standard configuration files or use a different key management backend. One more alternative is to use Castellan, a generic key management interface for OpenStack projects. This may be a viable long-term option depending on the progression of the project, but it's not viable in the short-to-medium term because no implementations of the interface have been merged yet. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- Using a key manager backed by Barbican will improve the security profile of Ironic by allowing operators of Ironic to swap keys out based on new cryptographic discoveries or security compromises. For example, if a particular cryptographic algorithm is known to be unacceptably vulnerable in the future, or if an attacker gains access to credentials used in Ironic, it will be easier to update the secret in Barbican than modify and deploy configuration changes across a large Ironic deployment. This change would make deployments that choose to use Barbican dependent on the security of Barbican for the secrets that are stored there. Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ This change will make deployments of Ironic that use Barbican to store secrets dependent on the availability of Barbican. This limits the scalability of such deployments to the scalability of their Barbican installation. Traffic used to store and retrieve keys from Barbican will be added for deployments that use this feature. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance impact of the initial storing and retrieval of keys should be negligible. Other deployer impact --------------------- For current password and token values that are stored statically in the configuration, there will be an optional sentinel value in the configuration for retrieving the key from the Barbican key manager implementation rather than from the config file itself. If the config value is not set to this sentinel value, the config value will be used. Developer impact ---------------- Developers who implement new drivers or other features that use secrets should use the key manager. Additional work to make current secrets use the key manager will need to be added over time for consistency. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mario-villaplana-j Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Develop generic key manager interface that can be subclassed. This should consist of methods that can easily be interfaced with python-barbicanclient. Develop subclass of generic key manager that pulls directly from configuration files. Develop subclass of generic key manager that implements the generic interface using python-barbicanclient. Develop example of usage of key manager for use with an existing secret in Ironic or one of its drivers. Add unit testing for the above. Dependencies ============ Adds a dependency for python-barbicanclient. Testing ======= Add Tempest testing to ensure that wrappers around Barbican calls function properly. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== No impact expected. Documentation Impact ==================== The use of the key manager, including how to update configuration files to use the Barbican implementation of the key manager and the default of using existing configuration values if the sentinel value to activate the Barbican key manager is not supplied, should be added. References ========== Castellan_ .. _Castellan: https://github.com/openstack/castellan

commit_message:
libvirt: log when BAD_LIBVIRT_NUMA_VERSIONS detected

This addresses a comment from the review on change
I6de388f1ca98c1ae16f2968f59881e3b0dba5f8d where we should log something
when a bad version of libvirt is detected for NUMA support.

Since the method is called from periodic tasks and when new instances
are created, we only want to log the warning once.

Related-Bug: #1449028

Change-Id: I6d3526ac892532a7b15e994391b1e86a619aa9c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/27/188427/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver.LOG, 'warn') def test_has_numa_support_bad_version_libvirt_log(self, mock_warn): # Tests that a warning is logged once and only once when there is a bad # BAD_LIBVIRT_NUMA_VERSIONS detected. drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) self.assertFalse(hasattr(drvr, '_bad_libvirt_numa_version_warn')) with mock.patch.object(drvr._host, 'has_version', return_value=True): with mock.patch.object(drvr._host, 'get_capabilities'): for i in xrange(2): self.assertFalse(drvr._has_numa_support()) self.assertTrue(drvr._bad_libvirt_numa_version_warn) self.assertEqual(1, mock_warn.call_count)

commit_message:
TESTING Fix OS_AUTH_URL to adapt to v3/v2.0 split

Without this patch, openrc and env vars get
passed directly through as-is without being
modified, but OS_API_IDENTITY_VERSION was,
causing breakage.

Change-Id: I0c4dbc74932bc2f78723fe41c4c7b6ff9df88d9e
Related-Bug: #1479879

Add docs check to os-ansible-deployment

This patch adds a gate check to os-ansible-deployment for
documentation in the repository.

commit_message:
Remove mariadb container

We don't need a mariadb container since the galera container does
exactly the same thing.  A followup patch will rename galera to
mariadb as soon as the galera remove-config-internal patches merge.

Change-Id: I3d1b31cf01e5584ebb1199e3e3ec63a2a32827bc
Partial-Bug: #1482987

commit_message:
Remove tox -egenconfig since its not needed for cinder

This operation fails to build.  We don't need a default config file
because config-external copies one in.

Change-Id: I9e47c7413189b1d921891c7654a6909249a84bb5
Partially-Implements: blueprint install-from-source

commit_message:
Revert "Make rsyslog catch all haproxy requests"

/etc/rsyslog.d/haproxy.conf is deleted if logging
task is run again. It needs to be updated before
we can rely on /etc/rsyslog.d/haproxy.conf to exist.

This reverts commit 8437578b654b25405e8302b5d464a83191c3ef60.

Change-Id: I3bdb836fcf11b8d2211d73610dd38e36ef75cc33
Partial-Bug: #1484069

commit_message:
Remove new auxiliary repo in case of rollback

Since we're managing auxiliary repo in puppet manifests (creating it)
and we don't have any sort of rollback puppet manifest, we need to
clean-up its artifacts in fuel_upgrade script.

This patch removed all newly created auxiliary repo in case of
rollback.

Depends-On: Iec2645ddbee6b1b6b9e5c2816707b275542ef51b
Closes-Bug: #1480282

Change-Id: If34406dd77aed45f19fa2f352bd23a0302716053
Signed-off-by: Igor Kalnitsky <igor@kalnitsky.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/89/211589/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: else: # By some pity reason we're managing auxiliary repo in puppet # manifests, but there's no management code for rollbacking. # Therefore, we need to clean-up its artifacts in case of # upgrade rollback procedure here; otherwise another try # of upgrade will fail. path, name = os.path.split( self.host_system_config['repo_aux_config_path']) utils.remove_if_exists(os.path.join(path, '{0}_{1}'.format( self.config.new_version, name)))

commit_message:
Test that get_hashes ignores only removed hash dir

Add test for case not yet covered by unit tests: suffix dir
has two hash dirs, one with expired tombstone. That hash dir gets
removed and its hash is not included in the suffix hash, but the
remaining hash dir's hash is reported.

Change-Id: I031a022daed6b8a66dfd04bea1b4d5eebcb882b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/94/208494/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_hash_suffix_one_reclaim_and_one_valid_tombstone(self): for policy in self.iter_policies(): paths, suffix = find_paths_with_matching_suffixes(2, 1) df_mgr = self.df_router[policy] a, c, o = paths[suffix][0] df1 = df_mgr.get_diskfile( 'sda1', '0', a, c, o, policy=policy) # scale back this tests manager's reclaim age a bit df_mgr.reclaim_age = 1000 # write one tombstone that's just a *little* older df1.delete(Timestamp(time() - 1001)) # create another tombstone in same suffix dir that's newer a, c, o = paths[suffix][1] df2 = df_mgr.get_diskfile( 'sda1', '0', a, c, o, policy=policy) t_df2 = Timestamp(time() - 900) df2.delete(t_df2) hashes = df_mgr.get_hashes('sda1', '0', [], policy) suffix = os.path.basename(os.path.dirname(df1._datadir)) df2_tombstone_hash = md5(t_df2.internal + '.ts').hexdigest() expected = { REPL_POLICY: {suffix: df2_tombstone_hash}, EC_POLICY: {suffix: { # fi is None here because we have a tombstone None: df2_tombstone_hash}}, }[policy.policy_type] self.assertEqual(hashes, expected)

subject: Replace 'import json' with oslo_serialization
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-11 21:39:59.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v2/json/token_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/token_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/credentials_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/network/json/network_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v2/json/identity_client.py', 'bin/neutron-rootwrap-xen-dom0', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/region_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/policy_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/service_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/identity_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/common/glance_http.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/services/identity/v3/json/endpoints_client.py', 'neutron/tests/tempest/test.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/eef7983d4ec829ba910a6c1000e8dac95efe50d3', 'message': "Replace 'import json' with oslo_serialization

commit_message:
Replace 'import json' with oslo_serialization

Replace remaining occurences of 'import json' with
'from oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json'
so pylint doesn't complain every time someone happens
to make a change to one of the modules that still
uses it.

Change-Id: Ife9f0fc54ad36887bdb939028f8903be16e590d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/56/211756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json

commit_message:
xstatic-package for Bootswatch Bootstrap Themes

Bootswatch provides many out of the box Bootstrap themes.
We plan on using this in Horizon to provide a theme that
implements Google's Material Design.

We plan on using this in Horizon to provide a theme that
implements Google's Material Design.

The 'material' theme gives an example of how to make use of a 3rd party theme
using the theming functionality.  In addition to incorporating a theme,
loaded as a static asset using requirements.txt, it also gives examples of how
to cleanly override styles, variables, icon fonts and Django templates.

This theme is replacing 'blue' as the example of how to use a theme other than
'default'.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg
Change-Id: I83753ca7f50d8e6d3051af4a7a929665e0de4d4d

&-nav, &-form { margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; } &-nav > li > a { @margin-vertical: ((@navbar-height - 2*@padding-base-vertical - @line-height-computed - 2px) / 2); margin: @margin-vertical 6px; padding: @padding-base-vertical @padding-base-horizontal; border: 1px solid transparent; border-radius: @border-radius-base; &:hover { border: 1px solid #ddd; } } &-nav > .active > a, &-nav > .active > a:hover { border: 1px solid #ddd; } &-default .navbar-nav > .active > a:hover { color: @navbar-default-link-hover-color; } &-inverse .navbar-nav > .active > a:hover { color: @navbar-inverse-link-hover-color; } &-brand { padding-top: ((@navbar-height - 2*@font-size-large) / 2); padding-bottom: ((@navbar-height - 2*@font-size-large) / 2); line-height: 1.9; } } @media (min-width: @grid-float-breakpoint) { .navbar { .navbar-nav > li > a { padding: @padding-base-vertical @padding-base-horizontal; } } } @media (max-width: @grid-float-breakpoint - 1) { .navbar { .navbar-nav > li > a { margin: 0; } } } // Buttons ==================================================================== .btn { font-family: @headings-font-family; } // Typography ================================================================= // Tables ===================================================================== // Forms ====================================================================== legend { font-family: @headings-font-family; } .input-group-addon { font-family: @font-family-sans-serif; } // Navs ======================================================================= .nav { .open > a, .open > a:hover, .open > a:focus { border: 1px solid #ddd; } } .pagination { font-family: @headings-font-family; &-lg > li > a, &-lg > li > span { padding: 14px 24px; } } .pager { font-family: @headings-font-family; a { color: @text-color; } a:hover { border-color: transparent; color: #fff; } .disabled a { border-color: @pager-border; } } // Indicators ================================================================= .close { color: #fff; text-decoration: none; text-shadow: none; opacity: 0.4; &:hover, &:focus { color: #fff; opacity: 1; } } .alert { .alert-link { color: @alert-success-text; text-decoration: underline; } } .label { font-family: @headings-font-family; font-weight: normal; &-default { border: 1px solid #ddd; color: @text-color; } } .badge { padding: 1px 7px 5px; vertical-align: 2px; font-family: @headings-font-family; font-weight: normal; } // Progress bars ============================================================== // Containers ================================================================= .panel { .box-shadow(none); &-default { .close { color: @text-color; } } } .modal { .close { color: @text-color; } }

commit_message:
xstatic-package for Google's Material Design Icons

MDI provides Google's Material Design Icons in SCSS format
We plan on using this in Horizon to provide a theme that
implements Google's Material Design.

The 'material' theme gives an example of how to make use of a 3rd party theme
using the theming functionality.  In addition to incorporating a theme,
loaded as a static asset using requirements.txt, it also gives examples of how
to cleanly override styles, variables, icon fonts and Django templates.

This theme is replacing 'blue' as the example of how to use a theme other than
'default'.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg
Change-Id: I356ce30e64daa13dd9ae8e5ed940b6b15982bd66

commit_message:
Bake in oslo sample config generation to sphinx build

The expectation from users is that to build docs locally all you need
to do is run build_sphinx on the repo and the docs will be fully
created. When we added the sample config to the tempest docs we ignored
this and just added the sample config generation to the docs tox job.
This commit fixes this by baking in the sample config generation to
the sphinx conf.py file which should ensure we have the sample config
generated every time that we call build_sphinx.

Change-Id: Ifd570707847f52592f5bc9bc743b8d3c98512639
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/44/211244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
xstatic-package for Roboto Font Face

Roboto is the font for Google's Material Design.

We plan on using this in Horizon to provide a theme that
implements Google's Material Design.

The 'material' theme gives an example of how to make use of a 3rd party theme
using the theming functionality.  In addition to incorporating a theme,
loaded as a static asset using requirements.txt, it also gives examples of how
to cleanly override styles, variables, icon fonts and Django templates.

This theme is replacing 'blue' as the example of how to use a theme other than
'default'.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg
Change-Id: I4773b35c18878e4bc20579eb21a7cc2cd8f7636e

commit_message:
Ironic: Use ironicclient native retries for Conflict in ClientWrapper

Ironic client has its own retries since 0.6, defaulting to 30 seconds.
As ClientWrapper also has retries (defaulting to 60 retries with
2 seconds break)), total retry time grows to 32 minutes (30*60+120)
by default, which is obviously insane.

I've seen this breaking deploy: if due to some race with ironic
nova will try to set instance_uuid on already active (or deploying)
node, it will take half an hour to fail, leading to all kind of timeouts.

Change-Id: I5351cfba43bd57957d7f55ef2c95e080b6080f73

commit_message:
Update the key manager API

Includes changes to the base API class to support managed objects
and creation of asymmetric key pairs. The current implementations
of the key manager only support symmetric keys for retrieval, and raise
NotImplementedErrors for generation of asymmetric key pairs. Full
functionality coming in later commits.

Change-Id: I69e0c22729413e95808f9419df59017011f14d99

commit_message:
tune tweaks::apache_wrappers class

 * use full path to commands to avoid
   cmd not found errors.
 * Do second stop only if first failed

Closes-Bug: #1472675

Change-Id: I43d662e5e7f91d6cf85f24d73792b654f1673cbc

commit_message:
Avoid to use python-ceilometerclient 1.4.0 in test

python-ceilometerclient doesn't seem to correctly use initilal
argument, like auth_url, though we pass it when we initialize
the client. The fail started after releasing ceilometerclient
1.4.0. So this tweaks tests for ceilometer_deriver that it
refrains from using ceilometerclient directory.

Closes-Bug: #1483831
Change-Id: Iac577dc7f35e65b84a078a0066e1f7533d550e0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/05/211705/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-ceilometerclient!=1.4.0,>=1.0.13

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Adds MigrationOps unit tests

The Hyper-V driver oldest tests (test_hypervapi.py) are proving hard to
maintain.

The tests in test_hypervapi.py in particular can also be refactored and
split in separate TestCases, one of each *ops module.

This commit refactors the MigrationOps test cases.

Co-Authored-By: Robert Tingirica <rtingirica@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Partially implements: blueprint hyper-v-test-refactoring-liberty

Change-Id: I9167cd9878175902a5b3293e9adc69045d1e8540

commit_message:
[WIP] Introduce callbacks to start/stop BGP route advertisements

This patch introduces callbacks for reacting to the appropriate user-initiated
actions such as floating IP associate/dis-associate, BgpSpeaker-network
binding/unbinding, and subnet create/delete.

This is a work-in-progress. BGP service plugin needs to register appropriate
callback methods, and callback invocations need to be inserted in the
appropriate places.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Change-Id: I3175bd592ba468963fe6b0b340bdbbc68a192b1d

commit_message:
Remove unneeded OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION

The desired OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION string is now reflected
in the oslo.db 1.12.0 release's default behavior, and so does not
need to be set any longer to achieve the same opportunistic backend
discovery for tests.

Change-Id: I004a53e077b465922bb08668b063ac1a55624eed

commit_message:
Add environment-apps-edit command

Adds a command, that allows editing editing apps of an environment.
Uses jsonpatch to manipulate object-model and puts all the results back
into the environment.

Targets blueprint: env-configuration-from-cli

Change-Id: I2b10d1c4374ab102741e160a5387a551ac76ce13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/59/208659/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import jsonimport jsonpatch @utils.arg("id", metavar="<ID>", help="Environment ID") @utils.arg("filename", metavar="FILE", nargs="?", help="File to read jsonpatch from (defaults to stdin)") @utils.arg("--session-id", metavar="<SESSION_ID>", required=True, help="Id of a config session.") def do_environment_apps_edit(mc, args): """Edit environment's object model.""" jp_obj = None if not args.filename: jp_obj = json.load(sys.stdin) else: with open(args.filename) as fpatch: jp_obj = json.load(fpatch) jpatch = jsonpatch.JsonPatch(jp_obj) environment_id = args.id session_id = args.session_id environment = mc.environments.get(environment_id, session_id) om = jpatch.apply(environment.services) mc.services.put( environment_id, path='/', data=om, session_id=session_id)

commit_message:
Sync with global requirements

Manually sync with global requirements to get newer pbr in.

Changes are:
    pbr>=0.6,!=0.7,<1.0            ->   pbr>=1.3,<2.0
    testtools>=0.9.36,!=1.2.0      ->   testtools>=1.4.0

Change-Id: Idf4d84db82e2369c7fce3597bc31895293f475cf

commit_message:
Prevent (un)pinning unknown CPUs

There's already a check to ensure pinned CPUs are unpinned and vice
versa, but none to ensure the CPUs are in the known set. Add one.

Closes-Bug: #1483613
Change-Id: Ie3c55912fbbd0e2e7b6dd48ca3c110c2d92fc987

commit_message:
Fix Ceilometer-driver auth_url failures

New versions of Ceilometer raise a fatal error if auth_url is empty.
This happens during testing because instead of mocking out the client,
we create it using an empty auth_url.

This patch fixes the problem by mocking out the ceilometer client during
testing.

Closes-bug: 1483899
Change-Id: Ib32bd248430fb214901d3216dcecbddc4e0d7d86
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/60/212060/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Add engines/ to API

This API endpoint allows us to interact directly with policy engines.

Change-Id: I7ef0a421eb9d7c57b9d7266db9f136174d61f34e

added_lines: network namespaces.</para> <para> By default, the DHCP and L3 agents use Linux Linux network namespaces and run in their own respevtive namespaces. commit_message:
Glance cannot store images due to incomplete configuration

Glance api refuses to store images with error
"Error in store configuration. Adding images to store is disabled. (HTTP N/A)"
This happens due to missing configuration of store in glance-api.conf

Change-Id: I50696671d10ffc56189d3aa08c1e73bb307bc800
Closes-Bug: #1484123

pci: Use fields.Enum type for PCI device status

us to remove a bunch of hard-coded strings.

subject: Split sahara and provisioning plugins
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-11 12:28:30.000000000', 'files': ['specs/liberty/split-sahara-and-plugins.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs/commit/1d59649d922c1463bde88ce2a3cf449cd412fb25', 'message': 'Split sahara and provisioning plugins

Change-Id: Ifae85dfbd65c625075c31d50a62b575ddcc0eeec
'}]
commit_message:
Split sahara and provisioning plugins

Change-Id: Ifae85dfbd65c625075c31d50a62b575ddcc0eeec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/13/190613/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Split Sahara main repository and provisioning plugins ===================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/sahara/+spec/move-plugins-to-separate-repo This specification proposes to move provisioning plugins into a separate repository. Problem description =================== The provisioning plugins are now a part of Sahara main repository. That means the plugin versions are strictly bound to Sahara version which is release twice a year. However the plugins and the Hadoop distribution they provide are usually updated more often. Also making plugins compatible with one ore more previous releases of Sahara will allow to deliver new content to older existing environments. Proposed change =============== The plugins should be moved to a separate repository sahara-plugins. Plugin specific tests should be moved there as well. The plugins should rely on the stable Sahara SPI and other utils. Making the SPI stable is critical for plugins so that they can be installed to older Sahara deployments. As there is almost no way to test plugins' functionality without sahara modules so sahara main project should be added as a test requirement for plugins. Sahara repository testing will also need plugins installed for running scenario tests but in this case the plugins should be installed manually so there will be no dependency on plugins in sahara. TBD: new plugin discovery mechanism. Alternatives ------------ TBD Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- The sahara and sahara-plugins repositories should be packaged and installed separately. Developer impact ---------------- The changes to the main sahara repository should be done only in the way that do not break plugins compatibility. The main modules to take care of are: * conductor * plugins base * plugins utils Sahara-image-elements impact ---------------------------- None Sahara-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Nikita Konovalov <nkonovalov@mirantis.com> Work Items ---------- * Make sure that there are no dependencies/imports of plugins in sahara main * Make all necessary updates and refactorings to plugin SPI and other modules and then freeze them * Move the plugins code to the sahara-plugin repo along with tests. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

Modify parameter type in Networking v2.0 ext

  description content in POST "metering-label-rules" api.

   request/response parameters table format.

commit_message:
Add support to lib/tempest for using tempest test accounts

This commit adds support to lib/tempest for configuring tempest to use
the test accounts mechanism. It adds a new variable
TEMPEST_USE_TEST_ACCOUNTS which will be used to trigger using test
accounts. The generate tempest-account-generator utility packaged with
tempest is used to generate the users and projects and write an
accounts.yaml. Another option TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY is added to specify
the the number of accounts to create, the value defaults to the number
of processors on the system.

The auth configuration section is moved to the bottom of the
configure_tempest function to ensure the proper auth endpoint and
catalog entries are all set in the tempest.conf file because the
tempest-account-generator tool depends on tempest knowing how to talk
to keystone to create the accounts.

Change-Id: I8682f72ffe26fd133874f5c575df6389f787ffcc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/77/210877/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Auth TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION=${TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION:-$TEMPEST_HAS_ADMIN} TEMPEST_USE_TEST_ACCOUNTS=${TEMPEST_USE_TEST_ACCOUNTS:-False} TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY=${TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY:-$(nproc)} if [[ -n $TEMPEST_USE_TEST_ACCOUNTS ]]; then if [[ -n $TEMPEST_HAS_ADMIN ]]; then tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $ADMIN_USERNAME --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD --os-tenant-name $ADMIN_TENANT_NAME -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY --with-admin etc/accounts.yaml else: tempest-account-generator -c $TEMPEST_CONFIG --os-username $ADMIN_USERNAME --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD --os-tenant-name $ADMIN_TENANT_NAME -r $TEMPEST_CONCURRENCY etc/accounts.yaml fi iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth allow_tenant_isolation False iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth test_accounts_file "etc/accounts.yaml" else iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth allow_tenant_isolation ${TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION:-True} fi iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth tempest_roles "Member"
deleted_lines: # Auth TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION=${TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION:-$TEMPEST_HAS_ADMIN} iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth allow_tenant_isolation ${TEMPEST_ALLOW_TENANT_ISOLATION:-True} iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG auth tempest_roles "Member"

commit_message:
Print error rather then backtrace on lack of stats

Both OpenStackAnsible and RpmPackaging generate backtraces when
running diversity.py because either there are not atleast two
reviews in stackalytics or two commits.  Solve that problem by
printing a message indicating no data is available at stackalytics
and return False in both cases.

Change-Id: I8ec989ae9ba3fd06a699bac9df107bbc85b7b8c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/92/211792/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if len(commits['stats']) < 2 or len(reviews['stats']) < 2: print '%-18s Unable to determine diversity because' % project print '%-18s this project is not available at stackalytics.com.' % '' return False

commit_message:
Print notice diversity couldn't be calculated

I18n has no deliverables assigned to it, so it is not possible
to measure diversity using dashboarding solutions.  To rectify
this situation, just print a message indicating diversity for
the specific project couldn't be calculated because it lacks
a deliverable.

Change-Id: If75c5eb7c0bcec8ef35fedc0e9f352efab0d7e3e

commit_message:
Moving RST format to main security-guide folder

This updates all scripts as well.

For further cleanup, changes for project-config (removal of jobs) and
openstack-manuals (stop sync of DocBook XML files) are needed first.

Implements: bp sec-guide-rst
Co-Authored-By: Andreas Jaeger <aj@suse.de>
Change-Id: I003f56c6d804f70cc74395bd947b053eb4cea769

commit_message:
General spec for the Liberty Installation Guide

Change-Id: Ie73882bd572a4a15234724bea74c92ff8a8dd88a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/docs-specs refs/changes/77/191077/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== OpenStack Liberty Installation Guide: Content Update ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/installguide-liberty When RST conversion is complete and when Liberty information becomes available, the OpenStack Installation Guide will be updated to Liberty. Refer to the Installation Guide RST conversion spec for more information about the RST conversion. Refer to the Installation Guide for Debian spec for more information about the Debian guide. Problem description =================== For the Liberty time frame, the following tasks need to be accomplished for the Installation Guide: * Liberty installation updates and testing Proposed change =============== When the RST conversion is complete and when information is available, add changes required to make the guide compatible with Liberty Optional enhancements to the guide as time and resources permit Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: karin-levenstein Other contributors: berendt dguitarbite jaegerandi ionosphere80 Work Items ---------- Add Liberty updates * TBD Dependencies ============ Liberty milestone or RC packages for each distribution supported by the Installation Guide. Testing ======= * All distributions supported by the Installation Guide must complete `testing`_ of at least core services (Identity, Image Service, Compute, and Networking) and successfully launch an instance using both legacy networking (nova-network) and Networking (neutron). Distributions that do not meet these criteria risk temporary removal from publication. .. _`testing`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/KiloDocTesting References ========== * Discussion can occur using any official medium including IRC in #openstack-doc, the openstack-docs mailing list with [install-guide] in the subject, weekly Installation Guide `specialty team meeting`_, weekly `documentation team meeting`_, and potentially etherpads. .. _`specialty team meeting`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/InstallGuide .. _`documentation team meeting`: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/DocTeamMeeting .. _`Liberty blueprint discussion`: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Documentation__Blueprint_Work_Session

commit_message:
Add os-brick based LibvirtVolumeDriver for ScaleIO

This patch adds a shim LibvirtScaleIOVolumeDriver calling the os-brick
library.

Both ScaleIO Cinder driver and ScaleIO connector driver in os-brick
were merged. The connector driver is available in os-brick 0.3.0
and later.

implements blueprint emc-sdc-libvirt-volume-driver

Change-Id: If2bba1f9d4c2ddfad7a26ca74bb61fe9ed6684ba

commit_message:
JSCS cleanup - eslint cleanup for openstack-service-api

Following John Papa's style guide, this patch cleans up
the Angular code for the openstack-service-api services.

Change-Id: Ia314b6521d2a5917dbd548d9c6e2663074cbc558
Partially-Implements: blueprint jscs-cleanup

commit_message:
Attach snapshot

This patch is a continuation of adding support for
non-disruptive backup. It implements attach snapshot,
leveraging the existing attach volume functionality.
Since this is used internally for backing up, the
attach snapshot interface is implemented in the manager
and driver, but not in the API layer.

Partial-implements blueprint non-disruptive-backup
Change-Id: I20dcc3fe18cd2f36504af9e3bf2567d0fff40cb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/56/198556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder import contextfrom cinder import objects def check_for_setup_error(self): # NOTE(xyang): If the service crashes or gets restarted during the # backup operation, there could be temporary volumes that are not # deleted. Make sure any temporary volumes create by the backup # job are deleted when service is started. cntx = context.get_admin_context() backups = objects.BackupList.get_all_by_host(cntx, self.hostname) for backup in backups: if backup.temp_volume_id and backup.status == 'creating': temp_volume = self.db.volume_get(cntx, backup.temp_volume_id) self._delete_volume(cntx, temp_volume) def backup_volume(self, context, backup, backup_service, orig_status): volume = self.db.volume_get(context, backup.volume_id) # NOTE(xyang): Check volume status; if not 'available', create a # a temp volume from the volume, and backup the temp volume, and # then clean up the temp volume; if 'available', just backup the # volume. temp_vol_ref = None if orig_status == "in_use": temp_vol_ref = self._create_temp_cloned_volume( context, volume) backup.temp_volume_id = temp_vol_ref['id'] backup.save() volume = temp_vol_ref if temp_vol_ref: self._delete_volume(context, temp_vol_ref) backup.temp_volume_id = None backup.save() def _create_temp_snapshot(self, context, volume): kwargs = { 'volume_id': volume['id'], 'cgsnapshot_id': None, 'user_id': context.user_id, 'project_id': context.project_id, 'status': 'creating', 'progress': '0%', 'volume_size': volume['size'], 'display_name': 'backup-snap-%s' % volume['id'], 'display_description': None, 'volume_type_id': volume['volume_type_id'], 'encryption_key_id': volume['encryption_key_id'], 'metadata': {}, } temp_snap_ref = objects.Snapshot(context=context, **kwargs) temp_snap_ref.create() temp_snap_ref = objects.Snapshot.get_by_id(context, temp_snap_ref['id']) self.create_snapshot(temp_snap_ref) temp_snap_ref.status = 'available' temp_snap_ref.save() return temp_snap_ref def _create_temp_cloned_volume(self, context, volume): temp_volume = { 'size': volume['size'], 'display_name': 'backup-vol-%s' % volume['id'], 'host': volume['host'], 'user_id': context.user_id, 'project_id': context.project_id, 'status': 'creating', } temp_vol_ref = self.db.volume_create(context, temp_volume) self.create_cloned_volume(temp_vol_ref, volume) self.db.volume_update(context, temp_vol_ref['id'], {'status': 'available'}) return temp_vol_ref def _delete_snapshot(self, context, snapshot): self.delete_snapshot(snapshot) context = context.elevated() snapshot._context = context self.db.volume_glance_metadata_delete_by_snapshot( context, snapshot.id) snapshot.destroy() def _delete_volume(self, context, volume): self.delete_volume(volume) self.db.volume_destroy(context, volume['id'])
deleted_lines: @abc.abstractmethod def check_for_setup_error(self): return def backup_volume(self, context, backup, backup_service): volume = self.db.volume_get(context, backup['volume_id'])

added_lines: from nova.virt.libvirt.volume import fsclass LibvirtScalityVolumeDriver(fs.LibvirtBaseFileSystemVolumeDriver): def get_mount_point_base(self): return CONF.libvirt.scality_sofs_mount_point def get_device_path(self, connection_info): """Returns the hashed path to the device. :param connection_info: dict of the form :: connection_info = { 'data': { 'sofs_path': the file system share ... } ... } :returns: The full path to the device. """ # TODO(mriedem): change the scality volume driver in cinder to set # the export and name keys rather than the sofs_path so this is # standardized. self.get_device_path(connection_info)
deleted_lines: from nova.virt.libvirt.volume import volume as libvirt_volumeclass LibvirtScalityVolumeDriver(libvirt_volume.LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver): def __init__(self, connection): """Create back-end to SOFS and check connection.""" super(LibvirtScalityVolumeDriver, self).__init__(connection, is_block_dev=False) def _get_device_path(self, connection_info): self._get_device_path(connection_info)

commit_message:
pci: Use fields.Enum type for PCI device type

Adds a new field type specialization for PCI device type, allowing
us to remove a bunch of hard-coded strings.

Change-Id: I1bd72cde1586a30454fee9da00cea1b1d65a53f9

added_lines: class UpdateForm(forms.SelfHandlingForm): definition_source = forms.ChoiceField( label=_('Definition Source'), choices=[('file', _('File')), ('raw', _('Direct Input'))], widget=forms.Select( attrs={'class': 'switchable', 'data-slug': 'definitionsource'}) ) definition_upload = forms.FileField( label=_('Definition File'), help_text=_('A local definition to upload.'), widget=forms.FileInput( attrs={'class': 'switched', 'data-switch-on': 'definitionsource', 'data-definitionsource-file': _('Definition File')} ), required=False ) definition_data = forms.CharField( label=_('Definition Data'), help_text=_('The raw contents of the definition.'), widget=forms.widgets.Textarea( attrs={'class': 'switched', 'data-switch-on': 'definitionsource', 'data-definitionsource-raw': _('Definition Data'), 'rows': 4} ), required=False ) def clean(self): cleaned_data = super(UpdateForm, self).clean() if cleaned_data.get('definition_upload'): files = self.request.FILES cleaned_data['definition'] = files['definition_upload'].read() elif cleaned_data.get('definition_data'): cleaned_data['definition'] = cleaned_data['definition_data'] else: raise forms.ValidationError( _('You must specify the definition source.')) return cleaned_data def handle(self, request, data): try: api.action_update(request, data['definition']) msg = _('Successfully updated action.') messages.success(request, msg) return True except Exception: msg = _('Failed to update action.') redirect = reverse('horizon:mistral:actions:index') exceptions.handle(request, msg, redirect=redirect)

commit_message:
Update requirements-deb

Usually, when we want install fuel w\o external internet, we use 
fuel-createmiror and ubuntu-part repos. But now it is not possible
to build ubuntu-bootstrap due lack of required packages.

Change-Id: I7d98fa7e7f9b811d901f45ecec9710c2a0e19a6f

commit_message:
Fix handling of toggleable group dependencies

* dependent role or settings don't block the whole group
* fixed setting group tooltip icon layout

Closes-Bug: #1484049

Related-Bug: #1483633

Change-Id: I78a55ecbb589dda64a803af04e546c1add87f313

subject: Improve Keystone Apache configuration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-04 13:02:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/6e8493801cc83e82e757043b57d320312ac4e5b5', 'message': 'Improve Keystone Apache configuration

This patch does the following:

1. Introduces two new variables which are useful for debugging
   the Keystone service. They default to the same values as
   before to ensure that there are no issues with changing
   behaviour.

   keystone_wsgi_processes: number of wsgi processes to run
   keystone_wsgi_threads: number of wsgi threads to run

2. Moves the keystone service and admin processes into their
   own groups for better isolation.

3. Sets each wsgi process to run under the keystone group.

4. Bring the configuration file in line with the upstream
   recommended configuration as at 4 Aug 2015.

Change-Id: I861d1ef233dd6121452dc0e9e590d2d9f9b7973e
Closes-Bug: #1481339
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-04 17:00:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/68bbaeb0bc0c948fbec67d1293323a9e37985436', 'message': 'Improve Keystone Apache configuration

This patch does the following for Keystone:

1. Introduces two new variables which are useful for debugging
   the Keystone service. They default to the same values as
   before to ensure that there are no issues with changing
   behaviour.

   keystone_wsgi_processes: number of wsgi processes to run
   keystone_wsgi_threads: number of wsgi threads to run

2. Moves the keystone service and admin processes into their
   own groups for better isolation.

3. Sets each wsgi process to run under the keystone group.

4. Bring the configuration file in line with the upstream
   recommended configuration as at 4 Aug 2015.

This patch also removes unnecessary python clients from the
tempest role as they introduce incompatible requirements
to the projects we deploy and support.

Change-Id: I861d1ef233dd6121452dc0e9e590d2d9f9b7973e
Closes-Bug: #1481339
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-04 18:19:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/ed7d3714b54d86a80c8c462d087fadddb7534a1d', 'message': 'Improve Keystone Apache configuration

This patch does the following for Keystone:

1. Introduces two new variables which are useful for debugging
   the Keystone service. They default to the same values as
   before to ensure that there are no issues with changing
   behaviour.

   keystone_wsgi_processes: number of wsgi processes to run
   keystone_wsgi_threads: number of wsgi threads to run

2. Moves the keystone service and admin processes into their
   own groups for better isolation.

3. Sets each wsgi process to run under the keystone group.

4. Bring the configuration file in line with the upstream
   recommended configuration as at 4 Aug 2015.

This patch also removes unnecessary python clients from the
tempest role as they introduce incompatible requirements
to the projects we deploy and support.

Closes-Bug: #1481339

commit_message:
Improve Keystone Apache configuration

This patch does the following:

1. Introduces two new Keystone variables which are useful for
   debugging the Keystone service. The values are defaulted
   to the same values as before the patch.
   - keystone_wsgi_processes: number of wsgi processes to run
   - keystone_wsgi_threads: number of wsgi threads to run

4. Moves the keystone service and admin processes into their
   own wsgi groups for better isolation.

5. Sets each wsgi process to run under the keystone group.

6. Bring the configuration file in line with the upstream
   recommended configuration as at 4 Aug 2015 in order to
   overcome import race conditions.

Change-Id: I861d1ef233dd6121452dc0e9e590d2d9f9b7973e
Closes-Bug: #1481339
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/47/209047/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: keystone_wsgi_threads: "{% ansible_processor_vcpus | default(2) // 2 %}" keystone_wsgi_processes: "{% ansible_processor_vcpus | default(1) %}"

commit_message:
Make the tox docs environment workable

tox -e docs does not work because of the following issue:

sphinx.errors.SphinxWarning:
os-ansible-deployment/doc/source/install-guide/configure-ceilometer.rst::
WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree

Directly using sphinx-build fixes this issue.

Change-Id: Iaaa1ce802e8c477baab21962a3dfa44dbc2b3a76
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/02/212002/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = sphinx-build doc/source doc/build

commit_message:
Revert "Add lock_path to cinder config"

This reverts commit d5c38006e8cd2690088555b93db29e69e8b507c1.

Change Ia94b17e24ec179a1804bc78c8defc25d63f7a4d3 breaks TripleO
CI (running Fedora). We should do this in a distro agnostic
way. Reverting for now, to unblock Fedora-based distros.

Change-Id: I2082c93553a0d72e1d25998be4c6ce0e19a6c202
Closes-Bug: #1482590

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary __ne__ implementations

The default python implementation of __ne__ delegates to __eq__ so none
of these are necessary.

Change-Id: I8b280b443e947f6462da82627f2e0a52a2c88993

commit_message:
Change serial console fake output from http to ws

Serial console will only work if a websocket URL is returned,
So we should not return 'http' in unit test which might
confuse people.

Closes-Bug: 1459943
Change-Id: I1519374c10d71147788ba6e7ea392cc87abbd854
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/95/198395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add non-negative integer and float fields

These changes were originally part of the 'Add object models' patch
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/128992/), but were separated out to
make them easier to backport into oslo.versionedobjects

Co-Authored-By: Jay Pipes <jaypipes@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alexis Lee <alexisl@hp.com>
Change-Id: I9688d3388d4543ce9c38f35a1ac90aabe79f2954
Partially-implements: resource-objects
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/49/206249/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NonNegativeFloat(FieldType): @staticmethod def coerce(obj, attr, value): v = float(value) if v < 0: raise ValueError(_('Value must be >= 0 for field %s') % attr) return v class NonNegativeInteger(FieldType): @staticmethod def coerce(obj, attr, value): v = int(value) if v < 0: raise ValueError(_('Value must be >= 0 for field %s') % attr) return v class NonNegativeFloatField(AutoTypedField): AUTO_TYPE = NonNegativeFloat() class NonNegativeIntegerField(AutoTypedField): AUTO_TYPE = NonNegativeInteger()

commit_message:
Rename starter-kit:compute file to match

The other tags translate with a normalized set of rules into filenames.
Specifically, -'s stay and :'s get translated to _. Let's align
starter-kit:compute.

Change-Id: I09b001ef9e01353178d2ee1885ac71be7cf80734

commit_message:
Use Senlin generic driver to manage neutron_v2 driver

Currently, neutron_v2 driver is only used in lbaas driver. Since
lbass is also an openstack driver module, it should directly invoke
'bare' neutron_v2 driver interface rather than senlin generic driver
interface.

Partially implement: blueprint reimplement-senlin-drivers-as-plugin
Change-Id: Iecfdbdb72b3cbf4fda4356006e216e03c7dd91d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/48/211848/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from senlin.drivers.openstack import neutron_v2 def NetworkClient(params): return neutron_v2.NeutronClient(params)

commit_message:
teamstats: Add stats related to team size.

Update the teamstats script to be able to determine the number of
active committers and active reviewers.

An active committer is defined as someone with 6 commits over the last
6 months.  An active reviewer is defined as someone with 30 reviews
over the last 6 months.  These values are completely arbitrary.  They
don't matter yet since no tag is defined that depends on it.

Change-Id: I80c1ae2fb5e5b3fed20475777cfbc0fa7f70b9b3
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/28/208028/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MIN_REVIEWS = 30 MIN_COMMITS = 6 def get_team_size_stats(team): team_stats = {} group = "%s-group" % team.lower() reviews = s.get('http://stackalytics.com/api/' '1.0/stats/engineers?metric=marks&release=all' '&start_date=%s&project_type=all' '&module=%s' % (six_months, group)).json() team_stats['active_reviewers'] = 0 for eng in reviews['stats']: if eng['metric'] >= MIN_REVIEWS: team_stats['active_reviewers'] += 1 team_stats['active_committers'] = 0 commits = s.get('http://stackalytics.com/api/' '1.0/stats/engineers?metric=commits&release=all' '&project_type=all&module=%s&start_date=%s' % (group, six_months)).json() for eng in commits['stats']: if eng['metric'] >= MIN_COMMITS: team_stats['active_committers'] += 1 return team_stats def print_team_size(team): team_stats = get_team_size_stats(team) print '%-18s (%6s | %6s)' % ( '', team_stats['active_committers'], team_stats['active_reviewers']) print ' (active committers | active reviewers)' print_team_size(project)

commit_message:
teamstats: Fix handling of teams with 0 commits.

Not all teams have commits and reviews in stackaltics.  The first
exmaple hit by this script is I18n.  This makes the script not blow up
in that case.

Change-Id: I892c5e451d41466d16b122d42e83ccef92e0adf6
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
diversity: Factor out policy from data gathering.

The diversity script had a single function that gathered a bunch of
stats from stackalytics and also determined whether the diversity
criteria was met.  Split the policy check out.  This is just a bit of
refactoring in preparation for adding some additional stats and policy
checks based on this code.

While we're at it, rename the script to 'teamstats', since this will
soon be looking at more than diversity.

Change-Id: I7993249b14cbb94a4700de10fc31bc0cd0394cf7
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Change Barbican service name

After discussing with the Barbican team we decided to change the project
from being a "Key Management Service" to being a "Key Manager Service".
This is to have a more uniform reference to Barbican.

Change-Id: I4ef6f1f5843d656ad1192f2cf050d9cafd755805

commit_message:
Make Swift endpoint type configurable

Currently, Ironic Inspector talks with Swift using public API endpoint.
This patch fix this by making endpoint type configurable and also make
default value "internalURL".

commit_message:
Ship the default image schema in the client

Now that we have stable branches for clients, it's easier to keep track
of the current default image's schema in Glance and update it
respectively. This patch adds the current image schema, including the
schema-properties.

One good reason to do this is to be able to react when a running Glance
instance is not around to be introspected. It's really unfortunate that
things like help text can't be rendered when there image schema is not
available in the system.

We could keep the schema in a json file but rather than shipping data
files with glanceclient we can just have it in the python modules.

Change-Id: I9b8cc1d18d6717ccf991fb8149ab13c06d653ee4
Closes-bug: #1481729

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from senlinclient import cliargs class TestCliArgs(testtools.TestCase): def test_add_global_identity_args(self): parser = mock.Mock() cliargs.add_global_identity_args(parser) expected = [ '--os-auth-plugin', '--os-auth-url', '--os-project-id', '--os-project-name', '--os-tenant-id', '--os-tenant-name', '--os-domain-id', '--os-domain-name', '--os-project-domain-id', '--os-project-domain-name', '--os-user-domain-id', '--os-user-domain-name', '--os-username', '--os-user-id', '--os-password', '--os-trust-id', '--os-token', '--os-access-info', '--os-api-name', '--os-api-region', '--os-api-version', '--os-api-visibility' ] options = [arg[0][0] for arg in parser.add_argument.call_args_list] self.assertEqual(expected, options) parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group.assert_called_once_with() group = parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group.return_value verify_opts = [arg[0][0] for arg in group.add_argument.call_args_list] verify_args = [ '--os-cacert', '--verify', '--insecure' ] self.assertEqual(verify_args, verify_opts) def test_add_global_args(self): parser = mock.Mock() cliargs.add_global_args(parser, '1') expected = [ '-h', '--version', '-d', '-v', '--api-timeout', '--senlin-api-version' ] options = [arg[0][0] for arg in parser.add_argument.call_args_list] self.assertEqual(expected, options)

commit_message:
Revert "Cleanup unneeded bug workarounds"

This reverts commit 08daf5dc1413b12871cf6adda9fa3a36aab35deb.

The change effectively enabled the new driver for all neutron
jobs, including those that run advanced services API tests,
which are not yet ready for it.

Original plan was to try a revert of a patch in fwaas
(I1777a3e6dc011524295edfcd9dbc037a8293f868) but then it was
dropped from the gate. Anyway, testing revealed it's not going
to fix the issue.

Since we should not leave neutron branches broken for
indefinite time, I propose this revert that should get us
back to stable neutron gate.

Without the issue solved, critical efforts like QoS feature
branch merge-back into master are effectively blocked. Also,
each neutron patch pushed into gate has a very high chance
to break and reset the queue, which affects other projects.

Related-Bug: #1483875
Change-Id: I45c7fb10c62e3440ca797497a81097ff0ecf90c3

commit_message:
Add API for rerunning failed task execution

Add put method to the TasksController that allows a failed task
execution to be re-run.

Change-Id: I185a9a5c594bb6d215c1c5b34efed9389bad0faa
Partial-Implements: blueprint mistral-workflow-pause-resume-with-intervention
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/43/202343/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from mistral.engine import rpc from mistral import exceptions as exc @rest_utils.wrap_wsme_controller_exception @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Task, wtypes.text, body=Task) def put(self, id, task): """Update the specified Task execution. :param id: Task execution ID. :param task: Task execution object. """ LOG.info("Update task execution [id=%s, task=%s]" % (id, task)) task_ex = db_api.get_task_execution(id) wf_ex = task_ex.workflow_execution if task_ex.state != states.ERROR: raise exc.WorkflowException('The current task execution must be ' 'in ERROR for rerun. Only updating ' 'task to rerun is supported.') if task.state != states.RUNNING: raise exc.WorkflowException('Invalid task state for rerun. Only ' 'updating task to rerun is supported.') wf_ex = rpc.get_engine_client().rerun_workflow(wf_ex.id, task_ex.id) task_ex = db_api.get_task_execution(id) task = Task.from_dict(task_ex.to_dict()) task.result = json.dumps(data_flow.get_task_execution_result(task_ex)) return task

subject: Identify disk for volume by 'extra' field
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-24 14:44:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/6d51035f7c0493336c6913c7550c0a7e9b0fa268', 'message': "Identify disk for volume by 'extra' field

Nailgun stores disk and volumes data separately: disk data in node's 'meta'
json blob, and volumes data in attributes for the node. User can't access the
attributes directly via API. Only node metadata is accessible.

In combination with known udev issue that breaks identification of devices by
PCI path [1], it can create a situation when disk identified differently in
volumes and in disk dicts.

This happens when during reboot from bootstrap to operating system after
provisioning udev changes the by-path linking of disks. The system ends up in a
situation like this:

  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0 -> ../../sdb
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part1 -> ../../sdb1
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part2 -> ../../sdb2
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part3 -> ../../sda3
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part4 -> ../../sda4
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part5 -> ../../sda5

This, in turn, causes KeyError exception when user tries to restore the disk
data on the node for reinstallation, or after moving to another environment.

Change-Id: I26bc2fc3cc01c3356710aac98a69c3c1a653c741
Closes-bug: 1477604

commit_message:
Identify disk for volume by 'extra' field

Nailgun stores disk and volumes data separately: disk data in node's 'meta'
json blob, and volumes data in attributes for the node. User can't access the
attributes directly via API. Only node metadata is accessible.

In combination with known udev issue that breaks identification of devices by
PCI path [1], it can create a situation when disk identified differently in
volumes and in disk dicts.

This happens when during reboot from bootstrap to operating system after
provisioning udev changes the by-path linking of disks. The system ends up in a
situation like this:

  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0 -> ../../sdb
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part1 -> ../../sdb1
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part2 -> ../../sdb2
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part3 -> ../../sda3
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part4 -> ../../sda4
  /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:01.1-scsi-0:0:0:0-part5 -> ../../sda5

This, in turn, causes KeyError exception when user tries to restore the disk
data on the node for reinstallation, or after moving to another environment.

Change-Id: I26bc2fc3cc01c3356710aac98a69c3c1a653c741
Closes-bug: 1477604

commit_message:
Unit test for client module

This patch adds unit test for the client module.

Change-Id: Id6d03800bb082a48f1586fa75185c9ddb696a49b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/27/211827/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from senlinclient import client as sc from senlinclient.common import utils class FakeClient(object): def __init__(self, session): super(FakeClient, self).__init__() self.session = session class ClientTest(testtools.TestCase): @mock.patch.object(utils, 'import_versioned_module') def test_client_init(self, mock_import): the_module = mock.Mock() the_module.Client = FakeClient mock_import.return_value = the_module session = mock.Mock() res = sc.Client('FAKE_VER', session) mock_import.assert_called_once_with('FAKE_VER', 'client') self.assertIsInstance(res, FakeClient)

commit_message:
upgrade: Enable possibility to use predefined requirements archive for upgrade module

* add posibility to pass http_link for tar file, which contain
all needed pips archives for upgrade-module

* add posibility to save artifact, which contain upgrade/deps files from
upgrade-module build process.

Change-Id: Idfc98971fbf72617cb73224f58f94cc484cc6e4e
